Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthesis and Reactivity of Polyaromatic Hydrocarbon Belts: Towards a Bottom-Up Organic Synthesis of Carbon Nanotubes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemistry Synthesis program is supporting the research of Professor Ramesh Jasti at Boston University. Professor Jasti will develop organic synthesis tools that will ultimately enable the preparation of structurally well-defined carbon nanotubes (CNTs). CNTs are among the most promising materials in nanoscience due to their unique electronic and optical properties. Current synthetic methods, however, produce CNT mixtures that have different arrangements of carbon atoms and, therefore, different physical properties. To achieve this goal, Professor Jasti and his group will develop syntheses of several polyaromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) belts - short fragments of carbon nanotubes. Aside from their relationship to CNTs, these structures have been long sought non-natural targets of synthesis for decades. A prerequisite to these syntheses is the development of methodologies that can construct highly strained PAHs. With these belt structures in hand, a Diels-Alder polymerization reaction to extend these belts into longer carbon nanotubes will be developed.

CNTs have shown promise as new solar energy materials, components of faster electronics, and single molecule biosensors. Syntheses of CNTs with well-defined, homogeneous structures will greatly facilitate engineers, physicists, and materials scientists in the development of these potentially revolutionary nanotechnologies. In addition to enabling new CNT technologies, the proposed program will train interdisciplinary scientists with the ability to apply complex molecule synthesis to problems in nanoscience. Professor Jasti's choice of synthetic targets will provide graduate and undergraduate students with a thorough background in synthetic organic strategy, methodology development, and reaction mechanism. In addition, in order to provide an interdisciplinary science experience to high school students, Professor Jasti will develop science workshops partnering with the Steppingstone Foundation and the Upward Bound Math and Science Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have remarkable properties that depend upon their exact diameter and atomic arrangement.  For example, some carbon nanotubes can be metallic with conductivities far superior to copper, whereas other carbon nanotubes can behave like semiconductors with varying band gaps depending on the exact structure.  Therefore, controlling the precise structure of carbon nanotubes is essential to realizing their possible applications.

 

The Jasti group approach to this problem is to use organic synthesis to prepare a short fragment of a carbon nanotube and then utilize this precursor as a “seed” to “grow” carbon nanotubes of predefined diameter and chirality.  We accomplished several aims in this grant period towards this ultimate goal of controlling carbon nanotube structure.  First, we developed scalable synthetic methods to prepare cycloparaphenylenes “or carbon nanohoops” of a variety of different diameters. Cycloparaphenylenes represent the shortest possible sections of armchair (metallic) carbon nanotubes.  Due to the harsh CNT growth conditions, wider “belt” structures are desirable for these molecules to serve as effective seed molecule for CNT growth.   With this in mind, we developed a variety of methods to append functional groups to CPPs that may undergo a late stage reaction that then would convert a CPP to a wider aromatic belt molecule.  We showed that both ring closing metathesis reactions and alkyne cyclizations can lead to partial belt structures.  Our reductive aromatization strategies to synthesize nonplanar systems, coupled with these extension strategies, allow access to unusual aromatic structures stretching beyond those just related to carbon nanotubes.  Moreover, in this grant cycle, we also provided experimental evidence that a Diels-Alder reaction was a viable reaction to “grow” CNTs from aromatic belt molecules.

 

From a broader impacts perspective, one of the central missions of this grant was to provide educational experiences that brought interdisciplinary science and nanoscience to a broad range of students. Over the course of the grant period, seven graduate students worked on the proposal (to varying degrees) and have gone on to receive their PhDs.  A total of 13 undergraduates have also worked on various aspects of this proposal. Finally, as is the case for many target oriented synthesis endeavors, one of the goals of our work was to develop synthetic methods and strategies that could be applied by others more broadly than the initial targets. We also anticipated that the chosen targets, conjugated molecules with unique geometric structure, would lead to new optoelectronic properties and applications reaching beyond their potential use as CNT templates. Numerous research groups all over the world have utilized our methods to make hoop like structures and other nonplanar aromatics. In addition, the CPPs and their derivatives are being widely studied across many fields including coordination chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, theoretical chemistry, photophysics, and most recently, biology. The synthetic strategies and methods developed in this proposal are having widespread impact on a variety of disciplines.
